natural problem: When Frederick was born, his grandparents gave him a gift of $\$2000$, which was invested at an interest rate of $5\%$ per year, compounded yearly.  How much money will Frederick have when he collects the money at the age of $18$? Give your answer to the nearest hundredth of a dollar.
natural solution: Five percent growth corresponds to multiplication by $1+5\%=1.05$.
So, the amount of money Frederick will have in $18$ years is $2000(1+.05)^{18}=\boxed{\$4813.24}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P r n t :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 2000"
and h1 : "r = 0.05"
and h2 : "n = 1"
and h3 : "t = 18"
and h4 : "P * (1 + r/n) powr (n*t) = 4813.24"
shows  "P * (1 + r/n) powr (n*t) = 4813.24"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When Frederick was born, his grandparents gave him a gift of $\$2000$, which was invested at an interest rate of $5\%$ per year, compounded yearly.  How much money will Frederick have when he collects the money at the age of $18$? Give your answer to the nearest hundredth of a dollar. The final Answer is \$4813.24
 ### Proof
 Five percent growth corresponds to multiplication by $1+5\%=1.05$.
 So, the amount of money Frederick will have in $18$ years is $2000(1+.05)^{18}=\boxed{\$4813.24}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P r n t :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 2000"
and h1 : "r = 0.05"
and h2 : "n = 1"
and h3 : "t = 18"
and h4 : "P * (1 + r/n) powr (n*t) = 4813.24"
shows  "P * (1 + r/n) powr (n*t) = 4813.24"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A principal amount of $2000 is compounded annually at an interest rate of 0.05 for 18 years. What is the final amount after 18 years? The final amount is $4813.24.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 2000"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> p * (1 + 0.05) powr n = p when he collects the money at the age of n"
shows  "p * (1 + 0.05) powr 18 = 4813.24"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When Frederick was born, his grandparents gave him a gift of $\$2000$, which was invested at an interest rate of $5\%$ per year, compounded yearly.  How much money will Frederick have when he collects the money at the age of $18$? Give your answer to the nearest hundredth of a dollar. The final Answer is \$4813.24
 ### Proof
 Five percent growth corresponds to multiplication by $1+5\%=1.05$.
 So, the amount of money Frederick will have in $18$ years is $2000(1+.05)^{18}=\boxed{\$4813.24}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 2000"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> p * (1 + 0.05) powr n = p when he collects the money at the age of n"
shows  "p * (1 + 0.05) powr 18 = 4813.24"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A person invests $2000 in a savings account that offers an annual interest rate of 5%. If the interest is compounded annually, how much money will he have in the account after 18 years? The final answer is $4813.24.
